title: Add Display config section to dox.toml
Implement markdown parser
description:
## Overview
Implement the markdown parser using gomarkdown/markdown library. Extracts headings and description from .md files.

## Dependencies
- gomarkdown/markdown dependency must be added
- Parser interface and utilities must exist

## Files to Create

### `internal/parser/markdown.go`
```go
package parser

import (
    "github.com/gomarkdown/markdown/ast"
    "github.com/gomarkdown/markdown/parser"
)

type MarkdownParser struct{}

func NewMarkdownParser() *MarkdownParser { return &MarkdownParser{} }

func (p *MarkdownParser) CanParse(path string) bool {
    return DetectFileType(path) == "md"
}

func (p *MarkdownParser) Parse(path string, content []byte) (*ParseResult, error) {
    // 1. StripBOM
    // 2. StripFrontmatter - check for title/description
    // 3. Parse markdown using gomarkdown parser with CommonExtensions
    // 4. Walk AST with ast.WalkFunc to extract headings
    // 5. Build description:
    //    a. If frontmatter has title/description, use those
    //    b. Else use first H1 heading text
    //    c. If H1 followed by paragraph, append: "Title - Paragraph text"
    //    d. If no H1, use first non-empty paragraph
    // 6. Return ParseResult with headings outline and description
}
```

**Key implementation details:**
- Use `parser.NewWithExtensions(parser.CommonExtensions)` to create parser
- Walk AST with `ast.WalkFunc(doc, func(node ast.Node, entering bool) ast.WalkStatus {...})`
- For headings: check `node.(*ast.Heading)` when entering=true
- Extract text from heading children (ast.Text nodes)
- Track line numbers by counting newlines in content up to node position
- Handle ATX headings (# style) - these are the standard ast.Heading nodes
- Handle empty files gracefully (return empty description, empty outline)
- Handle code-only markdown (no headings) - use first paragraph

### `internal/parser/markdown_test.go`
Table-driven tests:
- ATX headings: `# H1`, `## H2`, etc.
- File with frontmatter (title + description)
- File without frontmatter
- Markdown with only code blocks (no headings)
- Empty file
- Escaped headings inside code fences (should be ignored)
- Multiple H1 headings (use first)
- Deep heading hierarchy (h1 through h6)

## Patterns to Follow
- Follow existing test patterns in codebase
- Use t.TempDir() for any file operations
- Return errors wrapped with descriptive messages

## Acceptance Criteria
- `task lint` has zero warnings or errors
- `task build` succeeds
- `task test` passes including new tests
- Correctly extracts headings from real-world markdown files

## Commit
```bash
git add internal/parser/markdown.go internal/parser/markdown_test.go
git commit -m "feat: implement markdown parser with heading extraction"
```

title: Integrate manifest generation into sync
description:
## Overview
Hook manifest generation into the sync pipeline so that `dox sync` automatically generates/updates `manifest.json` after syncing files.

## Dependencies
- Manifest generator must be implemented

## Files to Modify

### `internal/sync/sync.go`
Add manifest generation after lock.Save():

```go
import "github.com/g5becks/dox/internal/manifest"

// In Run() function, after the lock.Save() block (~line 155):

// Save lock file
if !opts.DryRun {
    if saveErr := lock.Save(outputDir); saveErr != nil {
        return nil, saveErr
    }

    // Generate manifest (non-fatal)
    if genErr := manifest.Generate(ctx, cfg); genErr != nil {
        // Log warning but don't fail the sync
        if opts.OnEvent != nil {
            opts.OnEvent(Event{
                Kind: EventManifestError,
                Err:  genErr,
            })
        }
    }
}
```

Add new event kind:
```go
// In the EventKind constants:
EventManifestError EventKind = "manifest_error"
```

### `internal/ui/sync.go`
Handle the new event kind in SyncPrinter.HandleEvent:
```go
case doxsync.EventManifestError:
    fmt.Fprintf(p.w, "%s manifest generation failed: %v\n",
        p.s.warn.Sprint("⚠"),
        e.Err,
    )
```

### Test Updates
- Add test that verifies manifest.json is created after sync
- Add test that sync succeeds even when manifest generation fails (non-fatal)
- Verify manifest is NOT generated during dry-run

## Key Decisions
- Manifest generation is NON-FATAL: if it fails, sync still succeeds
- Manifest is NOT generated during dry-run
- Manifest is always fully regenerated (not incremental)
- The event system is used to communicate manifest errors to the UI

## Acceptance Criteria
- `task lint` has zero warnings or errors
- `task build` succeeds
- `task test` passes including new and existing tests
- Running `dox sync` on a configured project creates .dox/manifest.json
- Dry-run does NOT create manifest.json

## Commit
```bash
git add internal/sync/sync.go internal/ui/sync.go
git commit -m "feat: integrate manifest generation into sync pipeline"
```
